perturbation.original_text:
WHEREAS, the Member, by virtue of his or her position with Franchisee, will gain access to certain of Franchisor’s Confidential
Information, as defined herein, and must therefore be bound by the same confidentiality and non-competition agreement that Franchisee is bound
by.
perturbation.changed_text: WHEREAS, the Member, by virtue of his or her position with Franchisee, may gain access to certain information. The extent to which the Member is bound by confidentiality and non-competition agreements will be determined on a case-by-case basis and may not necessarily mirror the obligations of the Franchisee.
perturbation.explanation: The original text asserts that the Member 'must therefore be bound by the same confidentiality and non-competition agreement that Franchisee is bound by.' The modified text introduces ambiguity by stating that the Member's obligations 'will be determined on a case-by-case basis,' directly contradicting the original assertion of uniform obligation. This creates uncertainty regarding the scope of the Member's confidentiality and non-compete responsibilities.

perturbation.original_text:
1. Confidential Information. Member shall not, during the term of the Franchise Agreement or thereafter, communicate, divulge or use, for
any purpose other than the operation of the Franchised Business, any confidential information, knowledge, trade secrets or know-how which may
be communicated to Member or which Member may learn by virtue of Member’s relationship with Franchisee. All information, knowledge and
know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System (“Confidential Information”) is deemed confidential,
except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member’s attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the
time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.
perturbation.changed_text: 1. Confidential Information. Member shall not, during the term of the Franchise Agreement, communicate, divulge or use confidential information. However, after termination of the Franchise Agreement, the obligation to protect confidential information ceases unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the Franchisor. All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System (“Confidential Information”) is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member’s attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that the Member's obligation to protect confidential information extends 'during the term of the Franchise Agreement or thereafter.' The modified text introduces a contradiction by stating that 'after termination of the Franchise Agreement, the obligation to protect confidential information ceases.' This directly contradicts the initial statement, creating ambiguity about the duration of the confidentiality obligation.  The 'unless otherwise agreed to in writing' clause adds further uncertainty about the enforceability.

perturbation.original_text:
Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by
Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any
other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within a three (3) mile radius of the premises of your Franchised Business
or within a three (3) mile radius of any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System.
(d) As used in this Agreement, the term “Post-Term Period” shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date
of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the
cause for termination); (c) termination of Member’s employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of
arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the
enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or
entity).
perturbation.changed_text:
Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any
other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate. The applicability and scope of this clause are subject to local laws and may be modified by mutual agreement between the Member and the Franchisor.
(d) As used in this Agreement, the term “Post-Term Period” shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date
of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the
cause for termination); (c) termination of Member’s employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of
arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the
enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or
entity).
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes a clear restriction on competitive activities within a 3-mile radius during the Post-Term Period, 'except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor'. The modified text removes the geographic limitation and introduces the clause, 'The applicability and scope of this clause are subject to local laws and may be modified by mutual agreement between the Member and the Franchisor'. This addition significantly weakens the non-compete agreement by making its enforceability contingent on local laws and allowing for modifications through mutual agreement, thus contradicting the intention of a standard non-compete. It also eliminates the defined geographic radius. This could make it difficult for the Franchisor to prove a breach of the non-compete agreement.
